Class minimud.Player 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----minimud.Player
public class Player
extends Object
Handles all player related routines, with the inclusion of sending messages to players.

Version:
1.0
Author:
Tristan Greaves

con
Relevant connection class
e
Temporary storage for valid directions.
location
Location number.
n
Temporary storage for valid directions.
name
Character name.
objects_carried
Objects in inventory.
s
Temporary storage for valid directions.
status
Connection status.
w
Temporary storage for valid directions.

Player()
The no-arguments constructor is never used, and is here for Java syntax reasons only.
Player(Connection)
A player is first created when a connection is formed, so the constructor really doesn't have to do a great deal.

addToInventory(mudobject)
Add a mudobjecty to the player's inventory
getLocation()
Returns the number of the location where the player is.
getName()
Returns the name of the player.
getObjects()
Returns the objects carried.
getStatus()
Returns the player's Connection status.
giveConnection()
Returns the Connection associated with this player.
sendFile(String)
Sends the contents of the specified file to the player.
sendLine(String)
Sends a string to the player, terminating it with a carriage return.
sendLineNoCR(String)
Sends a string to the player, without terminating it with a carriage return.
sendLocation(int, Controller)
Sends the specified location to the player.
sendPrompt()
Sends our cheesy MiniMUD prompt the player.
setLocation(int)
Sets the player's current location.
setName(String)
Sets the player's name.
setStatus(int)
Allows the setting of the Connection status.

con 
 protected Connection con
Relevant connection class

status 
 protected int status
Connection status. There are three different valid status codes... 0 = Just Connected. 1 = At "Enter Your Name:" phase. 2 = Playing Game.

name 
 protected String name
Character name.

location 
 protected int location
Location number.

objects_carried 
 protected Vector objects_carried
Objects in inventory.

n 
 protected Integer n
Temporary storage for valid directions. This saves us having to reload the location data to check the validity of a players move. It contains 0 if that move is not possible. Otherwise, it contains the destination location.

e 
 protected Integer e
Temporary storage for valid directions. This saves us having to reload the location data to check the validity of a players move. It contains 0 if that move is not possible. Otherwise, it contains the destination location.

s 
 protected Integer s
Temporary storage for valid directions. This saves us having to reload the location data to check the validity of a players move. It contains 0 if that move is not possible. Otherwise, it contains the destination location.

w 
 protected Integer w
Temporary storage for valid directions. This saves us having to reload the location data to check the validity of a players move. It contains 0 if that move is not possible. Otherwise, it contains the destination location.

Player 
 public Player()
The no-arguments constructor is never used, and is here for Java syntax reasons only.

Player 
 public Player(Connection x)
A player is first created when a connection is formed, so the constructor really doesn't have to do a great deal.

giveConnection 
 public Connection giveConnection()
Returns the Connection associated with this player.

setStatus 
 public void setStatus(int s)
Allows the setting of the Connection status.

Parameters:
s - New status
getStatus 
 public int getStatus()
Returns the player's Connection status.

setLocation 
 public void setLocation(int l)
Sets the player's current location.

Parameters:
l - Location number
setName 
 public void setName(String s)
Sets the player's name.

Parameters:
s - Name
getLocation 
 public int getLocation()
Returns the number of the location where the player is.

getName 
 public String getName()
Returns the name of the player.

getObjects 
 public Vector getObjects()
Returns the objects carried.

addToInventory 
 public void addToInventory(mudobject o)
Add a mudobjecty to the player's inventory

Parameters:
o - Object to add
sendFile 
 public void sendFile(String s)
Sends the contents of the specified file to the player. This should really only be an ASCII text file, otherwise it it will do nasty things to the player's terminal!

Parameters:
s - Filename
sendLocation 
 public void sendLocation(int l,
                          Controller con)
Sends the specified location to the player. This involves sending the basic text description, displaying the available exits, along with any other players/objects that may be present.

Parameters:
l - Location number
con - Controller
sendLineNoCR 
 public void sendLineNoCR(String s)
Sends a string to the player, without terminating it with a carriage return.

Parameters:
s - String to send
sendLine 
 public void sendLine(String s)
Sends a string to the player, terminating it with a carriage return.

Parameters:
s - String to send
sendPrompt 
 public void sendPrompt()
Sends our cheesy MiniMUD prompt the player.
